content: Residential energy efficiency can benefit consumers by reducing utility bills and supporting national environmental policy objectives. Various policies have been adopted since the 1970s to increase conservation and energy efficiency, including tax incentives. The federal government is still deciding on the best policy tools to meet energy-efficiency objectives. In 2016, one-fifth of total energy consumed in the US was by the residential sector. Residential energy consumption has slightly decreased in recent years on a per capita and aggregate basis. Residential energy consumption has fallen slightly in recent years, both as a percentage of all energy consumption and on a per capita and aggregate basis. Per capita energy use has remained relatively constant since the 1970s but started trending downward in the mid- to late-2000s. Despite energy-efficiency gains, experts believe there is still potential for increased energy efficiency in the residential sector. Concerns exist that consumers may not invest in optimal energy efficiency levels, leading to debates on the optimal level of investment in energy efficiency. Increasing energy efficiency could potentially reduce residential energy use per capita. Energy efficiency in the residential sector remains a concern as consumers may not invest optimally. Tax credits are explored as a policy option to promote energy efficiency by addressing market failures and barriers. Tax incentives address market failures and barriers in residential energy efficiency. Taxpayers can claim credits for energy-efficient improvements and appliances for their primary residence. The Section 25C credit allows taxpayers to claim a tax credit for energy-efficient improvements on their primary residence, capped at $500. The credit expired at the end of 2017. Another credit, the residential energy efficient property tax credit (IRC §25D), allows for a tax credit on properties generating renewable energy. The Section 25C credit expired in 2017, and taxpayers cannot claim it anymore. The Section 25D credit allows for a tax credit on properties that generate renewable energy, with a 30% credit rate in 2017, decreasing to 26% in 2020 and 22% in 2021 before expiring. The maximum value of the Section 25D credit is not capped. For more details, refer to Appendices A and B. The Section 25D credit for renewable energy technologies is uncapped. A rational consumer would invest in energy-efficient technology if the savings outweigh the cost. However, some consumers do not make these investments, known as the "energy-efficiency paradox." Landlords and builders may also underinvest in energy efficiency, especially in non-owner-occupied housing, where the disconnect between decision-makers and end users can result in suboptimal energy-efficient investments. Consumers may underinvest in energy-efficient property due to high initial costs and lack of information. Low-income households, in particular, may settle for less efficient alternatives when unable to borrow funds upfront. Uncertainty about future energy prices can also deter consumers from making energy-efficient investments. The residential energy tax credit tends to be a passive reward at the end of the year, not a motivating factor for investment. The present-day residential energy tax incentives, introduced in 2005, are similar to the earlier incentives. The Energy Tax Act of 1978 introduced the first tax credit for conservation and renewable-energy generation, with a maximum credit value of $2,500. The Energy Policy Act of 2005 (EPACT05; P.L. 109-58) created new temporary tax credits for residential energy efficiency and renewable-energy property. These credits were in effect for 2006 and 2007, offering incentives for homeowners who made energy-efficiency improvements to their homes. The Energy Policy Act of 2005 (EPACT05; P.L. 109-58) introduced temporary tax credits for residential energy efficiency improvements in 2006 and 2007.
